intro: Pityopsis adenolepis, commonly known as the mountain dandelion, is a flowering plant native to the southern United States and parts of Mexico. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that resemble a single flower. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils, often in open woodland or mountainous regions. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while its flowers are yellow with a distinctive involucral bract. Pityopsis adenolepis is known for its ability to thrive in harsh, arid environments, making it an important component of its native ecosystems.
